title: Beneventano v. Gonzalez
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Kay Runay Beneventano, Appellant,
				v.
				Michael Gonzalez and Jenner Trucking & Construction, Inc., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â Â Â  2007-MO-031
Heard May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 4, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Max G. Mahaffee and Michael David Wood, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Kirby D. Shealy, III, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Connor v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 611 S.E.2d 905 (2005) (admission or exclusion of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and the trial courtâ€™s decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion); Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 485 S.E.2d 903 (1997) (to warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the wrongly admitted or excluded evidence); and Rule 701, SCRE (opinion testimony of lay witness is limited to those opinions or inferences which are rationally based on the perception of the witness, are helpful to a clear understanding of the witnessâ€™ testimony or the determination of a fact in issue, and do not require special knowledge, skill, experience or training).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michael Baxley, concur.

title: Bratcher v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Keith Bratcher, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF 
CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-032Â Â  

Submitted May 22, 2007 â€“ Filed June 4, 2007
DISMISSED AS 
IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of the South Carolina Commission of Appellate Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted certiorari to review the post-conviction relief courtâ€™s denial of relief to petitioner, Keith Bratcher.  After careful consideration, we now dismiss certiorari as improvidently granted.
DISMISSED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs, concur. MOORE, J., not participating.

title: Mitchell v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d) (2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Ben L. Mitchell, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-033
Submitted May 23, 2007 â€“ Filed June 4, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Colleen E. Dixon, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Reversed pursuant to Rule 220(b) (1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Edwards v. State, 372 S.C. 497, 642 S.E.2d 738 (2007) (Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an error of law); Clark v. State, 315 S.C. 385, 434 S.E.2d 266 (1993) (this Court will reverse the grant of PCR based upon after-discovered evidence where movant must fails to demonstrate the evidence: (1) is such that it would probably change the result if a new trial were granted; (2) has been discovered since the trial; (3) could not in the exercise of due diligence have been discovered prior to trial; (4) is material; (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching).
 
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. WALLER, J., not participating.

title: Hubbard v. Owens
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Kimberly H. Hubbard and John Hubbard, Respondents,
				v.
				Jack R. Owens, Marlboro 
				County 
				Farm Bureau, Ace Property and Casualty Insurance Company, Defendants,
				
				Of Whom Jack R. Owens is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marlboro County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-034
Submitted May 23, 2007 â€“ Filed June 11, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ronald J. Tryon and Michael E. Kozlarek, both of Parker Poe Adams & Bernstein, of
				
				Columbia, for Appellant.
				James C. Rushton, III, of the Hyman Law Firm, of
				
				Florence, for Respondents.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Respondents Kimberly H. and John Hubbard (â€œthe Hubbardsâ€) filed a lawsuit against Appellant Jack R. Owens (â€œOwensâ€) and two insurance companies.Â  On appeal, Owens argues that the trial court erred in denying his motion to dismiss the complaint, his motion for judgment on the pleadings, and his motion to compel arbitration of the Hubbardsâ€™ claims.
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authority:Â  Johnson v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services, __ S.C. __, 641 S.E.2d 895, 897 (2007) (providing that this Court will not entertain the merits of an issue on appeal where the record on appeal is inadequate for review); Woodard v. Westvaco Corp., 319 S.C. 240, 242-43, 460 S.E.2d 392, 393-94 (1995) (providing that the denial of a Rule 12(b)(1) motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order which is not immediately appealable); Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 477-78, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (providing that an order denying a motion for summary judgment is not appealable); Moyd v. Johnson, 289 S.C. 482, 482, 347 S.E.2d 97, 98 (1986) (holding that the denial of a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order which, ordinarily, is not immediately appealable); and South Carolina Dept. of Soc. Services v. Thompson, 273 S.C. 569, 571, 257 S.E.2d 747, 748 (1979) (providing that res judicata is an affirmative defense that must be pled to be established).
 
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. WALLER, J., not participating.

title: Williams v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Tomerio Williams, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Howard P. King, Post-Conviction Judge
James Williams, Trial Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-035
Submitted May 23, 2007 â€“ Filed June 11, 2007Â  

DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Lance S. Boozer, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  After careful consideration of the appendix and briefs, the writ of certiorari is
DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

title: Forest Lawn Company v. City of Goose Creek
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINAIn The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				Forest Lawn Company, Appellant,
				v.
				City of Goose Creek, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-036
Heard April 18, 2007 â€“ Filed June 11, 2007Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				J. Jay Hulst, of Williams & Hulst, LLC, of Moncks Corner, for Appellant.
				John P. Seibels, Jr., of The Seibels Law Firm, PA, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BURNETT: Â The trial court granted summary judgment to the City of Goose Creek (Respondent), finding the deeds which purported to convey property to Respondent are not void.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1967, Forest Lawn Company (Appellant) purchased property from Arista Corporation.Â  The property was located in the Colonial Heights subdivision near Goose Creek.Â  Appellantâ€™s note was secured by a mortgage on the entire property.Â  The first mortgage was held by Arista.Â  The second mortgage was held by Jack Brickman, the President of Arista, in the amount of $50,000.Â  In 1977, Arista and Brickman released their liens on lots 80-119[1] to Appellant after Appellant applied $35,000 toward the mortgage.Â  The releases were duly recorded in 1977.Â  Â 
Brickman filed a foreclosure action against Appellant for failure to make payments on the note in 1993.Â  At the hearing for the foreclosure action, Brickman testified: â€œA number of parcels and lots have been released from the lien of my mortgage; and, of course, these would be excluded from the foreclosure proceedings.â€Â  In 1994, the Master-in-Equity ordered the sale of the property â€œsaving and excepting therefrom, however, such tracts and lots which have heretofore been released from the lien of [Appellantâ€™s] mortgage.â€Â  Millwright Services, a junior lienholder, purchased the property and recorded the deed in 1995.Â  The Notice of Sale signed by the Master included the same language as the Masterâ€™s order, which provided an exception for certain lots previously released.Â  However, the deed and Notice of Sale specifically included lots 80-83 as part of the property conveyed.Â  Appellant filed a motion to reconsider which was denied.Â 
 
In 1998, Millwright Services conveyed its interest in lots 80-83 to Respondent under a general warranty deed.Â  Respondent purchased title insurance on the property.Â  After Appellant discovered the conveyance, he repeatedly notified Respondent of his alleged interest in lots 80-83 and provided copies of all the pertinent documents to prove the Masterâ€™s deed was erroneous. Â 
In 2005, Appellant filed a complaint in Berkeley County alleging, inter alia, (1) the deed conveying property to Respondent is void insofar as it relates to lots 80-83; (2) the Masterâ€™s deed conveying property to Respondentâ€™s predecessor-in-interest, Millwright Services, as a result of the foreclosure action erroneously included lots 80-83 and was, therefore, void; and (3) Appellant is the rightful owner of lots 80-83.Â  The trial court granted Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment, holding the deeds in dispute are not void because the foreclosure action from which they originate is not void.Â  The trial court also found Respondent qualified for protection under the bona fide purchaser doctrine, and Appellantâ€™s failure to address the alleged error of the deed for almost ten years rose to the level of laches and waiver, which bar the action.Â  Appellant responded by filing this appeal.Â 
 
ISSUES

	
		
			 I.
			Did the trial court err in 
			holding the Master had authority to effect the sale of the property when lots 80-83 had been released from the mortgage?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			finding Respondent was a bona fide purchaser?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 626 S.E.2d 1 (2006).Â  A trial court may properly grant a motion for summary judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 611 S.E.2d 922 (2005).Â  The appellate court, like the trial court, must view all ambiguities, conclusions, and all inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 550 S.E.2d 319 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Authority of the Master
The trial court held the conveyance of lots 80-83 under the Masterâ€™s deed was valid and, in doing so, mistakenly focused on subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Whether the Masterâ€™s judgment was a proper exercise of jurisdiction is not an issue.Â  Rather, the issue is whether the Master had authority to effect the sale of lots 80-83 when the lots had previously been released from the mortgage.Â  We hold the Master did not have such authority.Â 
 
It is well settled that a deed cannot convey an interest which the grantor does not have in the land described in the deed, even though by its terms the deed may purport to do so. Â Cummings v. Varn, 307 S.C. 37, 42, 413 S.E.2d 829, 832 (1992) (citing Griggs v. Griggs, 199 S.C. 295, 19 S.E.2d 477 (1942)).Â  This long-standing principle applies with equal force to the foreclosure of a mortgage and title conveyed under a Masterâ€™s deed.[2]Â  The Masterâ€™s deed could not convey title to lots 80-83 because those lots were no longer subject to the mortgage.Â  The erroneous inclusion of lots 80-83 in the Notice of Sale and deed does not change this fact.Â  Therefore, the trial court erred in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment and determining the Masterâ€™s deed conveyed title of lots 80-83 to Respondent.
II.Â  Bona Fide Purchaser
Appellant argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Respondent based on the alternative ground Respondent was a bona fide purchaser.Â  We agree.
A bona fide purchaser is protected from anotherâ€™s claim to property when: (1) the purchase money was paid before notice of any outstanding encumbrances or equities; (2) the purchaser acquired legal title, or the best right to it, before notice of the outstanding encumbrances or equities; and (3) the purchaser purchased in good faith and without notice.Â  S.C. Tax Commâ€™n v. Belk, 266 S.C. 539, 543, 225 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1976).Â  
 
The issue is whether Respondent had notice lots 80-83 had been released to Appellant.Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-7-10 (2007), deeds or instruments conveying or releasing real property are valid to subsequent purchasers without notice when they are recorded.Â  Respondent cannot claim it was without notice of the release of lots 80-83 when such release had been properly recorded in 1977.Â  Therefore, Respondent was not a bona fide purchaser.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the trial court and hold Respondent was not entitled to summary judgment because the Master did not have authority to effect the sale of lots 80-83 when the lots had previously been released from the mortgage, and because Respondent was not a bona fide purchaser when it had record notice of such release.Â  We remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â Â  Accordingly, we need not address Respondentâ€™s laches and waiver arguments.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S .E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining the appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Of the 39 lots released from the mortgage, only lots 80-83 are at issue.
[2] See Belue v. Fetner, 251 S.C. 600, 606, 164 S.E.2d 753, 756, (1968) (â€œThe mortgage executed by Florence Belue necessarily covered only the life estate interest which she acquired under the deed from Ola Belue for that was all that she had; and the Masterâ€™s deed in the foreclosure could convey no more.â€); Bethea v. Bass, 240 S.C. 398, 126 S.E.2d 354, 360, (1962) (â€œThe mortgage from Thomas M. Bethea, Sr., in 1925, though purporting to include the fee, covered only his life estate, for that was all that he had; and the Masterâ€™s deed in the foreclosure could convey no more.â€).

title: Borghi v. Dismuke
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Carlo Borghi, Appellant,
				v.
				Robert C. Dismuke and Allcare Tree Surgery, Inc., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-037
Â Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David Holt Berry, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				E. Mitchell Griffith, of Beaufort, for Respondents.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed pursuant to Rule 220 (b)(1) and the following authorities:Â  Gray v. Southern Facilities, Inc., 256 S.C. 558, 183 S.E.2d 438 (1971); see also Bridger v. Asheville & S.R. Co., 27 S.C. 456, 3 S.E. 860 (1887).

				In Re: State of South Carolina, Respondent,

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-038
Heard May 23, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18, 2007Â Â  
DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


	
		
			
				Andrew F. Litvin, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Â Solicitor Robert M. Arial and Assistant Solicitor G. Dennis Sims, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision in Ex parte A-1 Bail Bonding Co., Op. No. 2005-UP-604 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 1, 2005).Â  We dismiss the writ as improvidently granted.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Michael G. Nettles, concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        Davenport Properties, a SC General Partnership, Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina Department of Transportation; Connector 2000 Association, Inc.; 
          Interwest Carolina Transportation Group, LLC; and Interwest Management, Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-039
Heard May 22, 2007 â€“ Filed June 25, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Howard W. Paschal, Jr., of Price, Ashmore & Beasley, PA, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Beacham O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia, and Peter A. Rutledge and J.
          Richard Kelly, both of Leatherwood, Walker, Todd and Mann, of Greenville, for
          Respondents.
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authorities:Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 550 S.E.2d 319 (2001)
  (summary judgment standard); Hardin and Tallent v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of
    Transp., 371 S.C. 598, 641 S.E.2d 437 (2007) (road closings and
  realignments which do not take land from a property owner do not give rise to
  compensable takings); Hill v. The Beach Company, 279 S.C. 313, 301
  S.E.2d 604 (1983) (a prescriptive right to ocean view, breezes, light and air
  does not exist in South Carolina).
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Michelle Childs,
concur.

title: State v. Bennett
text:

<!--

.style2 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-weight: bold; }
-->



THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Gary Bennett, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Horry County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2007-MO-040
  Heard February 14, 2007 â€“ Filed June 25,
  2007Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief
          Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General
          William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, and John Gregory Hembree, of
          Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  We granted
  certiorari to review a Court of Appealsâ€™ decision finding error but no
  prejudice in the trial courtâ€™s impeachment ruling, and affirming petitionerâ€™s
  murder and armed robbery convictions.Â  State v. Bennett, Op. No.
  2004-UP-439 (S.C. Ct. App. filed August 13, 2004).Â  We affirm.
Petitioner
  was charged with murdering and robbing the victim, an acquaintance, in her
  home.Â  The Stateâ€™s case rested, almost exclusively, on the testimony of Andrew
  Lindsay.Â  Lindsay admitted being in the trailer when petitioner killed the
  victim, but denied having prior knowledge of petitionerâ€™s plans or assisting
  him in committing the murder or the armed robbery.Â  Although petitioner
  presented no evidence, he sought to suggest through cross-examination that
  Lindsay had gone to the trailer alone and committed both offenses.
At the
  outset of the trial, the State made a motion in limine to limit
  Lindsayâ€™s impeachment by his 1991 conviction for second degree murder in Illinois.Â  Specifically, the State sought and obtained a ruling limiting the impeachment to
  the fact that Lindsay had been convicted of a felony carrying a 15 year
  sentence.Â  The Court of Appeals held that while the trial judge erred in
  limiting Lindsayâ€™s impeachment, petitioner was not prejudiced by that ruling.
ISSUE

  
    Whether the Court of Appeals erred in finding petitioner was not
      entitled to a new trial because the trial court improperly limited his
      impeachment of Lindsay?
  

ANALYSIS
Rule
  609(a)(1), SCRE, provides:

  (a) General Rule.Â  For the purpose of attacking the credibility of a witness,
  
    (1) evidence that a witness other than an
      accused has been convicted of a crime shall be admitted, subject to Rule 403,
      if the crime was punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year
      under the law under which the witness was convicted, and evidence that an
      accused has been convicted of such a crime shall be admitted if the court
      determines that the probative value of admitting this evidence outweighs its
      prejudicial effect to the accusedâ€¦.
  

According to the reporterâ€™s
  notes, the same standard for balancing prejudice against probative value under
  Rule 403 is employed, whether the person to be impeached is a witness or a
  criminal defendant.
The reason for
  permitting a jury to learn of a witnessâ€™s prior conviction is to allow the
  jurors to use the conviction in evaluating the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  Rule
  609.Â  Once the trial judge determines the witness has a qualifying prior
  conviction, he must then apply a Rule 403 balancing test.Â  In weighing
  prejudice and probative value, a trial judge must take into account
  similarities between past convictions and present charges.Â  Close similarities
  weigh against admissibility.Â  State v. Bryant, 369 S.C. 511, 633 S.E.2d
  152 (2006). 
Here, the crime for
  which petitioner was on trial, and for which he wished to shift suspicion to
  Lindsay, was murder.Â  Had the judge wished, he could have excluded Lindsayâ€™s
  prior homicide conviction altogether on the ground that prejudice outweighed
  any probative value.Â  In permitting Lindsay to be impeached by his prior
  offense, but prohibiting disclosure of the nature of the crime, the trial judge
  removed the possibility that the jury would impermissibly use the prior
  conviction to adjudge Lindsay guilty of this murder, rather than use the
  conviction to evaluate his credibility.Â  Thus, petitioner was not deprived of
  the impeachment value inherent in Lindsayâ€™s prior conviction.
â€œAn appellate court
  will not disturb a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning the scope of
  cross-examination of a witness to test his credibilityâ€¦absent a manifest abuse
  of discretion.â€Â  State v. Johnson, 338 S.C. 114, 525 S.E.2d 515 (2001).Â 
  We perceive no abuse of discretion here.
CONCLUSION
The decision of the
  Court of Appeals affirming petitionerâ€™s convictions is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      Carolyn Chester, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Sherman E. Boutte, Jr., Appellant,
      v.
      South Carolina Department of Public Safety, South Carolina Department of Transportation and South Carolina Forestry Commission, Respondents.
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
  Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-042Â Â  
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 25, 2007

DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Robert
          N. Hill, of Newberry; and Mark B. Tinsley, of Godding & Gooding, P.A., of
          Allendale, for Appellant.
        Marvin
          C. Jones, of Bogoslow, Jones, Stephens & Duffie, of Walterboro, for
          Respondent South Carolina Department of Public Safety.
        Lisa
          A. Reynolds and Eric M. Johnsen, both of Anderson & Reynolds, of Charleston, for Respondent South Carolina Department of Transportation. 
        Roy
          P. Maybank, of Maybank Law Firm, of Charleston, for Respondent South Carolina Forestry Commission.
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Dismissed
  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR,
  and the following authorities:Â  Ex
    parte Wilson, 367 S.C. 7, 625 S.E.2d
  205 (2005) (generally only final judgments are appealable, but an interlocutory
  order may be immediately appealable if it falls under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330);
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 & Supp. 2006) (interlocutory orders
  involving the merits or affecting a substantial right are immediately
  appealable); Mid-State
    Distribs., Inc. v. Century Importers, Inc., 310
  S.C. 330, 334, 335 n.4, 426 S.E.2d 777, 780, 780 n.4 (1993) (An interlocutory
  order involving the merits is one that â€œmust finally determine some substantial
  matter forming the whole or a part of some cause of action or defense.â€Â  An
  interlocutory order affects a substantial right when it will â€œdiscontinue an
  action, prevent an appeal, grant or refuse a new trial, or strike out an action
  or defense.â€).Â 
  
DISMISSED.
 TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Eric Castro, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-044
Heard June 7, 2007 â€“ Filed June 25, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission
          on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all
          of Columbia, and Solicitor David Michael Pascoe, Jr., of Summerville, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR,
  and the following authorities:Â  State
    v. McWee, 322 S.C. 387, 472 S.E.2d 235 (1996) (a constitutional
  argument is unpreserved for appeal where appellant failed to raise the argument
  at trial); State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5-6, 377 S.E.2d 581,
  584 (1989) (a party cannot argue one ground for a directed verdict at trial
  and then an alternative ground on appeal).Â  
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
